instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Oh Boy A lot of Work
threads.message:
Hi, I'm currently working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I bought the device myself with water damage, so please don't be too hard on me if I have done something wrong up to this point, I mainlywanne study this repair matter to get into this
I would also like to apologize in advance for my bad English.

The seller said an apple repair shop said the device was water damaged but after I opened the device I don't noticed any corrosion or red indicators

At the beginning I only got 5V from the charger after swapping <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, the device ran again and I was able to boot everything wonderfully in IOS after I took both chips off the board to use it for another board for testing I must have created a short circuit when soldering it again I definitely only got 5V from the charger after I got 2 new chips and then soldered them to the board <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> burnt out with a hole And this is where the fun begins. After swapping both chips again, I finally got 20V from the charger  But no S5 Rails I traced this problem back to the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> chip which did not output a <SIGNAL>PMIC_PGD</SIGNAL> signal after swapping <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> the voltages match and I get <SIGNAL>PP3V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> but no boot, the fan turns when I connect it after some back and forth I noticed that <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G_PH1</SIGNAL> / 2/3 was missing What I was able to trace back to a missing <SIGNAL>GTVR_FCCM</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets 0V on pin2 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL>) I was able to fix this after I replaced <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR> and then the board drew about 500mA and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> got very hot I think I had a short circuit on Pin2 but I'm not quite sure after swapping the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but this was fixed <SIGNAL>GTVR_FCCM</SIGNAL> is now 1.6V
Now I notice that <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> are getting very hot and <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> are mine even after I have noticed Resistance to ground of <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> only at 40Ohm (Black probe on ground) I exchanged <DIODE>D3400</DIODE> now the resistance is 1. 1K Ohm, however, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are still very hot but get 20V and round about 300mA from the charger now I'm standing on the hose and could use some help Thanks in advance I'm looking forward to learning something new

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Oh Boy A lot of Work
threads.message:
Pufff, not sure if this board can still be recovered.

When a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip dies with hole in, sometime CPU, or SMC,  can get killed too.
This happens because when <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> silicium die melts, overvoltage can arrive to CPU, or SMC, through data lines.
Many times the USB redriver chip (PI3USB32224) get killed also.

iGPU voltage (VCCGT) will not appear at boot; only comes on under high graphics load.

Both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips cannot heat at the same time, as only one is connected to VBUS.
What voltages do you get on the board now?

Check for short at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and F7000.
About how to use diode mode, read here.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Oh Boy A lot of Work
threads.message:
Thank u for u response

I get a bad chipjust aboveY3000 its not shown on my BRD view so i thinks this could be the PI3USB32224 chip it was verry hot too i swaped this chip too

You are right its only one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> at the time getting hot

the tipp with VCCGT is good for me thank you

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 20,29V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 13,03V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5,1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 5,1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5,1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 1,8V


Board Takes roundabout 250mA



Diod Readings with red on GRD:

F7000: 0,420V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>(Pin2): 0,545V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>(Pin1) : 0,545V
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSI_N</SIGNAL> (Pin3) :0,545V
<SIGNAL>TBA_SCI_P</SIGNAL>(Pin4): 0,545V

In Louis Videos i heard somethink om CPU VCore so some kind of feed raild for the cpu somethink around 1V i sthink so o looked up the board and i get 1V on L8060 (<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G_REG</SIGNAL>) and L7900 (<SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL>)
This Voltages are for the PHC i think so

I Diod and Resistance tested on L8060 and L7900 too this values are quit low but i think luis says in his videos a low resistance to GRD on CPU rails can be normal i hop i dont fry my PHC here right now this will be the 3. board in a row with bad PHC

L8060:
DIod (Red on GRD) (Pin2): 0,076V
Resistance(black on GRD): 92,7 Ohm

L7900:
DIod (Red on GRD) (Pin2): 0,090V
Resistance(black on GRD): 76,3 Ohm

On L7210(<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0H_PH1</SIGNAL>) and L7220(<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0H_PH2</SIGNAL>) i get 0V i think this is the CPU main Power rail right here ?

L7210:
DIod (Red on GRD) (Pin2): 0,004V
Resistance(black on GRD): 4,5Ohm

L7220:
DIod (Red on GRD) (Pin2): 0,004V
Resistance(black on GRD): 4,4 Ohm


I cant messure the Right Values from another baord all of my <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board just have no CPU On it

[UPDATE]

I figured out a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>(29,1Ohm to GRD // 0,026V Diod) and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>(62,3Ohm
 to GRD // 0,054V Diod)
I will invest some time in this problem later this day maybis this will fix my hot <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip problem.



Thanks in advance for ur time for helping me out

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Oh Boy A lot of Work
threads.message:
Do you get any voltage at L7210/20?
If yes, measure final level, 10-15s after applied power on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Oh Boy A lot of Work
threads.message:
Okay i Changed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> again and my short on  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> is now gone the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> area is not feeling hot anymore ...
meanwhile i have a hole boneyard with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips only from this board ... but its okay its still fun for me to figure out this kind of failure 

Now i invest some time and messure around the missing <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> coming from L7210/20 i catch some values from <CHIP>U7220</CHIP> but I don't quite know what to do with it  so here we go:

Pin 3 (<SIGNAL>VCINP_P5V_U7320</SIGNAL>) :   5,1V 
Pin 29 (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>) :                  5,1V
Pin 8 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>) :     13V
Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_FCCM</SIGNAL>) :            2,2V
Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PWM2</SIGNAL>) :           0V and no kind of puls or oscilating 
Pin 5 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_BOOT2</SIGNAL>) :          4,814V

I searched for somethink like a datasheed for the FDMF5808A (<CHIP>U7220</CHIP>) and I found something similar a datasheed for an FDMF5821 â€“ Smart Power Stage (SPS) Module with Integrated Temperature Monitor in the picture i can see a simular inputs like on the FDMF5808A (<CHIP>U7220</CHIP>) so i think i can go with it
after i figure out all supply voltages are there (PVCC,VCC,VIN) and i get an EN sinal from <SIGNAL>CPUVR_FCCM</SIGNAL> i think so the onlysignal the chip is missing to work is a PWM Signal <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PWM2</SIGNAL> i think so

<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PWM2</SIGNAL> is coming direct from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> which I have changed before 
Voltage at Pin 42 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL>) is present with 5,1V also Pin 41 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL>) with 13V some kind of ENABLE signal on Pin 48 (<SIGNAL>PM_EN_CPUVCC_R</SIGNAL>) is also present with 3,2V Pin 47 (<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_CPUVCC</SIGNAL>) is also present wits 3,3V
The qestion for me is now were doesthe PWM/CLOCK signal comes from ? is <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> Producing its own sinal ? the only CLK sigal on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is SCLK maybe somethink with system clock ? but this siganl / lane is coming from <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> (Page 8 SYM 12 of 20 ) witch is powerd by <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> if i see it right witch is EN from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> if i see this right this is very confusing for me and I am currently turning in circles

values for an overview:

Pin 41 (<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL>) : 13V
Pin 48 (<SIGNAL>PM_EN_CPUVCC_R</SIGNAL>) : 3,2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Oh Boy A lot of Work
threads.message:
Previous communication between PCH and some part of CPU is required.
BIOS is also involved and VCORE is controlled through <SIGNAL>CPU_VID</SIGNAL> bus.
Most likely bad CPU.

Do you get L7370 and L7730 voltage?

24MHz and 12MHz are Present

After replacing the chip still same result 20V 200mA No boot
I figured out that <SIGNAL>CPU_ZVM_L</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7790</CHIP> is missing so no <SIGNAL>PPVCCOPC_S0G</SIGNAL> for the CPU too 
so maybe last option dead CPU ?


feels bad that i fried a working system just by soldering a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> not properly but so far i learnt a bunch off stuff with this bord

so maybe i overlooked something maybe someone else has a hint or a tip for me?


Until now thank you very mutch for helping me out with this probelm :)

[UPDATE]

Don't give up too soon

and the only issue can be a bad solder join at <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> I don't remember exactly but i think on Pin 48 or on Pin47 so after cleaning and resoldering <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again i finaly get my <SIGNAL>PPVCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> and my <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0G</SIGNAL> back with 1V 
Board is taking 20V and round abou 470mA now after holding the powerbutton down board turn off 20V 60mA after pressing again i seems to start/boot ? nah dont know its doing somethink it will take 20V 470mA again but no Backlight or somethink else at this moment CPU is getting slightli warm at this moment 

how many amts a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> takes in boot phase or after boot ? 
what rails i can check next for geth further with this problem ?
